data.title: Disappointed
data.text:
I had lunch here with friends and had high hopes for this new restaurant.  The remodel of the space was inviting but a little noisy partly because we were seated under the music speaker.  Waitress was pleasant and knew the menu.  Unfortunately the menu is limited and expensive for what you get.  The wine 
was VERY expensive and the pours seemed small although we were assured it was a 5 oz pour.  But $18 for a mediocre red?  Beer list was short,all imported and unknown to us.  Most were large bottles so no way to see if you like it before buying.  The food itself was well prepared and presented.  Portions were adequate.  That is the only reason I gave it the rating I did.  I may try one more time to see if it improves but it will be a while.

data.title: Hip place with good food and excellent wine list
data.text: Celebrated my husband's birthday a few days ago. The place is modern and hip in decoration, very nice to look at. The menu is shockingly short and prices are average to high. The wine list, on the other hand, is extensive and offers many rare hard to find wines, although it also reflects the unusually high prices. There are very few wines under $50, average runs from $80 to $130, with many into $200 plus range. The food is well done and nicely plated. Portions are fine if you are not a big eater. Service is attentive, but not exceptional. Certainly not a place for regular visits, unless, budget is no problem. Perhaps the management should think about attracting more local residents by reworking the menu and wine list. Hard to say if we are going back.

data.title: Love the looks but...
data.text:
Pretty place with great design and branding (nice logo), but, we've been here twice and each time service or the kitchen has been less-than-stellar. My husband and I really, really want to like this place, because Santa Rosa needs another good restaurant. So far, this isn't good, just average...but maybe someday, if they keep trying!
Word of warning, when booking make sure to ask for a first floor table. The upstairs area is under-decorated and the ambiance is lacking (that would be alright if you got an upper floor dining discount, but you don't).
Rather than give you a litany of what went wrong, let me just say that we will be back but with adjusted expectations. This place has potential, but needs to work on being a well-oiled machine by getting out the entrees on time (one of our entrees was forgotten) and working on food quality (one of our rib eye steaks was too fatty to consume). We had the same issues the first time we went to CB, too, or I would just assume our average experience was an aberation.

data.title: Breakfast
data.text: Came in on a Sunday for breakfast before leaving the area. Very nice decor and large bar. I was not impressed with my meal which was a skillet dish, with potato, pancake and poached egg. Seemed to lack seasoning and not much bacon. The ladies had mimosas which were very small, all champagne with a splash of juice, I guess if you want to get drunk at breakfast at $10/crack why not but neither of them seemed happy with the presentation. We had a teenager with us that just wanted scrambled eggs or a plain omelette and was told he could not have it. I hate when they do this to pickier eaters, so not jazzed about that, especially since we were the first ones there and it was not busy yet. One of the others in our party ordered the waffle with strawberries and cherries and when it arrived it was apples. The waiter said nothing when he delivered it but upon questioning he said that the other fruits were out of season, would have been nice to know this before ordering.The bloody mary I had was good. I would come here again as the service was good and the restaurant was very nice, maybe better luck with lunch or dinner.

data.title: We will definitely return!
data.text: My husband and I went for our anniversary last week.  It was mid week and I have to say we were delighted by the amazing plates that came out of the kitchen.  First, the decor is beautiful!  Gorgeous bar, walls and seating.  Friendly staff.  We had a glass of sparkling, a glass of Pinot, Brussels sprouts, clams, salmon and a farm bowl.  All delicious!  Great spices.  A wonderful addition to our list of go to places in Santa Rosa.  We will be back.

data.title: Sorry, not a fan
data.text: I just had lunch here.  I am a native of Sonoma County, so know the local cuisine well.  This place is pricey with not a lot of inviting things on the menu.  The caesar salad was good enough, but $15?  The pork sandwich was just okay, messy and super salty (and I'm a girl who likes some salt).  There were nuts in the orange spread which was not cool either and it was served with a "salad" on the side.  I've got to say, I am tired of people calling poorly dressed lettuce a salad.  That's it, lettuce with a bit of dressing on it.  The wine is outrageously priced!  $15-$18 for a 5 ounce pour.  I actually saw a bottle of Rochioli pinot noir for $248.00!!!!  I am not kidding.  Once I picked my jaw up from the floor I noticed that it was a 1990, but really?????  I don't think you can find a bottle of wine for under $50 and this is wine country folks.  If you go across the street to La Rosa, you will have some great eats for half the price (perhaps skip the wine though, since their pride is tequila).  Super disappointed.  Maybe it's a try for a Michelin star or something, but in my opinion it's a complete miss.

data.title: Breakfast treat
data.text:
Cool vibe with brick wall on one side and rough wood and glass shelves on the other (the bar area).  

Order the waffle croque madame and the skillet.  Delish. If you want a good breakfast with style, this is the place.

data.title: Definitely worth a re-visit
data.text:
We chose the County Bench through open table to celebrate our wedding anniversary.
We were provided a lovely table with attentive service and recognition of our special evening. 
The menu made it difficult for us to choose with so many unique dishes, hence the reason to return, however next time, we will return for happy hour at their sophisticated and lively bar. 

Regardless of what type of dining experience you want (casual, special, group) this is a great display of local Sonoma County faire. 

Starters:
Deviled Brussel Sprouts
Roasted Hamachi Collar
Aaaaaaazing

Entrees:
Double Pork Chops
Salmon
Side: cauliflower, brown butter, braised oxtail. 

(Pork Chops were Delicious! Hubby's Salmon lacked flavor and excitement, but scored big in presentation.)
Cauliflower.... couldn't get enough!

Deserts:
Creme banana brûlée 
Some cocoa delicious bar of goodness.

data.title: So sad, too bad
data.text: Disappointing at best! Heard about this new venue & decided to give it a try. After several days of traveling & connecting with great food & wine venues we were extremely disappointed. Unwelcoming bar & wait staff, over priced mediocre food....raw chicken legs...pink, stringy, rubbery skin, $4 popcorn that we thought would be awesome...stay home, pop your own with Brewers yeast....yep all of 25 cents....oh & the $8 Naan bread....two pieces from Trader Joes....not to mention the wine menu.....French & Italian...in the heart of Cali wine country....poured from a machine....robotic at best, not what we were looking for, for sure 😞

data.title: Not what I would like it to be
data.text:
I really want to like this place. But I think in the end I don't. Too many dishes are not what they should be. For instance, the mussels.They are undercooked lukewarm and tough, sometimes, which would be OK if they gave you a decent portion. But they do not. And they refuse to serve them with bread, essential to being able to sop up the sauce (which is pretty good). 

Another defect: They serve their wine out of kegs, and it just does not taste as good as wine from a bottle. Plus, they serve the white wines way to warm. I appreciate that many white wines at many restaurants are served too cold, but the wine in your glass needs to be a little cool so you can appreciate it as it warms.

And I do wish they had a better selection of gins if you are in the mood for a martini.

data.title: Incredible food presentation & flavors- Wine & Cocktail choices Cool
data.text: Had Cocktails and appetizers - Fingerling Potatoes with aioli & deviled Brussel Spouts and lunch next day- superb service setting décor- ambiance first class presentation unique pairing of flavors - portions -  Family owned - parking in back - great Happy Hour value and choices

data.title: New restaurant in old location on Fourth Street
data.text: We read about this place before visiting Santa Rosa and were pleased by our lunch time visit early this month. Menu more ambitious than usual lunch places, and service of a more polished standard. Would like to try it in the evening as well.

data.title: Delightfully inventive chef
data.text: Our first time there impressed us with the creative menu of small dishes, 3 of which, with a salad were plenty for two of us, making the meal moderate in price.  The Hamachi collar and crispy chicken were particularly delicious.  Desserts were small - don't expect to share - but unusual and satisfying.  Worth the visit inspite of current construction in the area.

data.title: Lively restaurant with craft cocktails
data.text: We went with friends for dinner.  Make reservations!  A small menu but fun to share appetizers.  The popcorn with corn, chicken thighs and perfectly cooked fingerling potatoes with creme fraiche were all wonderful.  Large menu of cocktails and sitting at the bar seems popular.  We ordered two desserts that were delicious, the creme brûlée and I can't remember the name of the other but it was like a peanut butter brûlée.  That one was outstanding.  Our server was very nice, but still think they are working out the serving kinks.

data.title: Very Tasty Downtown Lunch
data.text: High quality food, friendly service, a central downtown location! Five of us, two residents of PA and three from Germany, found a truly fine lunch during our one-day visit to Santa Rosa. Everything was perfectly cooked, nicely seasoned, and thoroughly enjoyed.

data.title: Stopped here for Sunday brunch
data.text: I had heard good things about The County Bench and stopped today to enjoy brunch with my spouse. It seems that there are still a few logistics that need to be ironed out - we came in the back door, creating some confusion at the hostess station. It was apparent that they could have used more servers today as the upstairs area was vacant and the outside patio area (on an absolutely gorgeous day) were closed. There were still a few tables open, but we were informed that the wait would be 15-20 minutes. We spotted a pair of seats at the bar and asked if eating there was an option, which it was, but the option wasn't suggested. The staff was pleasant enough but you could clearly see there was some stress on their faces. Nonetheless, the food was really good and the atmosphere was appealing. I have high hopes for this restaurant and I'm a supporter for its success. Let's see what happens on my next visit.

data.title: A definite destination..a jewel on 4th St.
data.text:
I had been wanting to eat here since they opened, having a huge amount of respect for Chefs Bruce and Ben. They certainly haven't let us down with this menu!
I think we tried half of it. :)
The grilled short ribs were amazing, the popcorn+corn was a unique offering, the butter lettuce and Arugula salad was great and aesthetically pleasing with the plums and pistachios. The naan bread was tasty, and the cast iron rice, grains with olives, herbs had some serious depth.
The real show stopper was the braised chicken thighs with chorizo and pimenton. Wow and yum!
Had a delightfully strong mojito and a damn good glass of wine with all that food. Unfortunately, I am not much of a wine drinker so I don't recall what it was, but they have a sommelier on hand to help us beer drinkers keep up...and they offer beer too.
Finished off with a semifreddo topped with Bing cherries.
The decor is cute as hell. I went out on a limb and got a reservation. While they weren't yet full up on a Saturday at 6:30pm, the reservation got us the lone love seat booth that lets you watch everything from the bar, to the dining room, to a bit of the kitchen. It was fun to see the place get crazy busy when all the other people came in to enjoy this jewel on 4th Street.
These guys are doing a great job.

data.title: wonderful swordfish & great ambiance
data.text:
This is an aggregate 3.5 review, not a full four...

CBKB is still finding their way but my companion and I had a satisfying meal there on a Tuesday night. Amazingly, downtown SR was hopping. We started with marinated goat cheese with toasted crostini and it was very nicely herbed & spices. [I had tasted the grilled short rib adobo a few weeks back and thought it a good appetizer, if a bit skimpy.

Friend has the Ribeye Steak (for two) and I had the swordfish with hazelnuts, citrus over a very nice broccolini. A very refreshing, well prepared dish. Friends big steak was nicely cooked-- but the cut had some tough spots that could have been dealt with. I was not wild about the 'rub' but she liked it.

CBKB should really amp up their wines by the glass list. There was only one Rose and it was not amazing. This is So Co, there should be 20+ wines by the glass.. and not all local. The second Pinot I got was good, but nothing to rave about. They really promote their sommelier service and bar experience but I think it is a bit limited at this point. The staff needs to be educated about their wines, or the somelier should step in.

Sadly, we did not do dessert but everything on the dessert menu looked great. Expresso topped off our nice meal. 

I just felt our server seemed fairly new and a little too shy, but she did a nice job overall. Also, I think the owner was there and he could have come over an introduced himself. I just always want a bit more TRUE hospitality for a Santa Rosa dining experience.

data.title: Nice option if you are in the area but not worth going out of your way
data.text: My wife and I gave this place a try after hearing someone speak very highly of it.  It is certainly a diamond in the rough. I would not have expected to find such a nice restaurant in that area.  The wine selection is very nice, and the staff was outstanding (especially the sommelier).  Unfortunately, we were not very impressed with the food.  It was good, but it certainly did not stand out.

data.title: A nice surprise
data.text: This gem is on a street perhaps better known for cheap eats for students. Lovely interior, nice decor, polite and attentive staff. We found the menu items we tried, such as the deviled Brussels sprouts, to have surprising yet pleasing flavor combinations. The sommelier was very helpful in sorting out the long wine list and matching our taste preferences with some wines we had never tried before. All quite lovely - do try them out!
